 How DVR Works
  A DVR is basically a glorified hard drive inside a fancy box that looks nice in your entertainment center. But the digital storage of television signals opens up a whole new world of possibilities when it comes to playback and viewing. Learn how a 
DVR lets you pause live TV, skip the commercials and record every instance of a program, even in high-definition!
 Also at HowStuffWorks
 

How Netflix Works - When Reed Hastings founded Netflix in 1997, DVD players
had only been on the market for a few months. Nearly 10 years later, Netflix
has nearly 6.8 million subscribers. Find out how the Netflix movie rental system
works and learn about its shipping process.
 

How Spyware Works - According to recent estimates, more than two-thirds of all
PCs are infected with some kind of spyware. This malicious type of program infiltrates your computer, tracks your Web habits 
and more. Learn all about spyware and how you can get rid of it.
 

How FoIP Works - If
you've ever sent a fax from a computer, you've used a form of Fax over Internet
Protocol (FoIP). FoIP combines the benefits of traditional faxing with the cost
savings of Internet transmission methods. Learn how faxing over the Internet
works. 
   
This Week's Video
 

Which MP3 players make good video players? - If you're looking for an MP3 player to watch
your favorite movies or TV shows on, check out the models in this HowStuffWorks
video. They've got big, bright LCD screens and are packed with memory to hold
hundreds of hours' worth of video and music files.
